DataElement.preferredName: Biologically-Derived Material Specimen Requirement Type Molecular Specimen Type Text Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Natural substances derived from living organisms such as cells, tissues, proteins, and DNA.:A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.:Something that is necessary; condition, something that is obligatory._A subdivision of a particular kind of thing._Relating to or produced by or consisting of molecules.:A sample or part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._Text; the words of something written._Type; a subdivisino of a particular kind of thing.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Natural substances derived from living organisms such as cells, tissues, proteins, and DNA.:A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.:Something that is necessary; condition, something that is obligatory._A subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Natural substances derived from living organisms such as cells, tissues, proteins, and DNA.:A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.:Something that is necessary; condition, something that is obligatory.

Concepts.definition: Natural substances derived from living organisms such as cells, tissues, proteins, and DNA.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.
Requirement; something that is necessary.

Property.preferredDefinition: A subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/28/10 Released for use in caTissue Suite version 1.1 and/or 1.2 per owners direction.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Laboratory methods used to generate cells that are able to reproduce indefinitely.: A species of Herpetoviridae that is responsible for infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). Discovered in 1964, this virus has been associated with Burkitt's lymphoma in South African children and with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Asian populations.

Concepts.definition: Laboratory methods used to generate cells that are able to reproduce indefinitely.

A species of Herpetoviridae that is responsible for infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). Discovered in 1964, this virus has been associated with Burkitt's lymphoma in South African children and with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Asian populations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Coming next after the first in position in space or time or degree or magnitude.: This technique refers to selectively replicate DNA sequence of interest to multiple extra copies that meet the need of research or health care activity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be considered a type of man-made gene amplification process.: A proprietary method for whole genome amplification (WGA) from small samples using high-fidelity enzyme Phi 29 polymerase to amplify complex genomic DNA using Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA) technology.: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: Coming next after the first in position in space or time or degree or magnitude.

This technique refers to selectively replicate DNA sequence of interest to multiple extra copies that meet the need of research or health care activity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be considered a type of man-made gene amplification process.

A proprietary method for whole genome amplification (WGA) from small samples using high-fidelity enzyme Phi 29 polymerase to amplify complex genomic DNA using Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA) technology.
A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary method for whole genome amplification (WGA) from small samples using high-fidelity enzyme Phi 29 polymerase to amplify complex genomic DNA using Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA) technology.: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary method for whole genome amplification (WGA) from small samples using high-fidelity enzyme Phi 29 polymerase to amplify complex genomic DNA using Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA) technology.
A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This technique refers to selectively replicate DNA sequence of interest to multiple extra copies that meet the need of research or health care activity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be considered a type of man-made gene amplification process.: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: This technique refers to selectively replicate DNA sequence of interest to multiple extra copies that meet the need of research or health care activity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be considered a type of man-made gene amplification process.
A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary method for whole genome amplification (WGA) from very small samples using random fragmentation of genomic DNA and conversion of the resulting small fragments to a library of PCR-amplifiable molecules flanked by universal priming sites.: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary method for whole genome amplification (WGA) from very small samples using random fragmentation of genomic DNA and conversion of the resulting small fragments to a library of PCR-amplifiable molecules flanked by universal priming sites.
A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

Concepts.definition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Single-stranded complementary DNA synthesized from an RNA template by the action of RNA-dependent DNA polymerase. cDNA (i.e., complementary DNA, not circular DNA, not C-DNA) is used in a variety of molecular cloning experiments as well as serving as a specific hybridization probe.

Concepts.definition: Single-stranded DNA that is complementary to messenger RNA or DNA that has been synthesized from messenger RNA by reverse transcriptase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of a group of complex organic macromolecules that contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and usually sulfur and are composed of one or more chains of amino acids. Proteins are fundamental components of all living cells and include many substances, such as enzymes, hormones, and antibodies, that are necessary for the proper functioning of an organism.

Concepts.definition: A group of complex organic macromolecules composed of one or more chains (linear polymers) of alpha-L-amino acids linked by peptide bonds and ranging in size from a few thousand to over 1 million Daltons. Proteins are fundamental genetically encoded components of living cells with specific structures and functions dictated by amino acid sequence.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

Concepts.definition: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: 1. The process of formation of poly(adenylic acid). 2. The covalent modification of a macromolecule (e.g., mRNA) by the formation of a polyadenylyl moiety covalently linked to the macromolecule.

Concepts.definition: The enzymatic addition of a sequence of adenylyl residues at the 3' end of an RNA molecule.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: That portion of the cell contained within the plasma membrane but excluding the nucleus.: A nucleic acid molecule similar to DNA but containing ribose rather than deoxyribose. RNA is formed upon a DNA template. There are several classes of RNA molecules. They play crucial roles in protein synthesis and other cell activities. (MedicineNet.com)

Concepts.definition: That portion of the cell contained within the plasma membrane but excluding the nucleus.
Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the nucleus.: A nucleic acid molecule similar to DNA but containing ribose rather than deoxyribose. RNA is formed upon a DNA template. There are several classes of RNA molecules. They play crucial roles in protein synthesis and other cell activities. (MedicineNet.com)

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the nucleus.
Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genomic DNA sample produced from a pool of samples from several subjects that is amplified using REPLI-g technology.

Concepts.definition: A genomic DNA sample produced from a pool of samples from several subjects that is amplified using REPLI-g technology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An RNA sample derived from a formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: An RNA sample derived from a formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A DNA sample derived from a formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A DNA sample derived from a formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.: A species of Herpetoviridae that is responsible for infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). Discovered in 1964, this virus has been associated with Burkitt's lymphoma in South African children and with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Asian populations.: Laboratory methods used to generate cells that are able to reproduce indefinitely.

Concepts.definition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

A species of Herpetoviridae that is responsible for infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). Discovered in 1964, this virus has been associated with Burkitt's lymphoma in South African children and with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Asian populations.
Laboratory methods used to generate cells that are able to reproduce indefinitely.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A collection of DNA molecules that have been cloned in vectors.  In the case of a cDNA library the DNA inserts are copies of RNAs that have been reverse-transcribed into DNA prior to cloning.

Concepts.definition: A collection of DNA molecules that have been cloned in vectors.  In the case of a cDNA library the DNA inserts are copies of RNAs that have been reverse-transcribed into DNA prior to cloning.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin slice of tissue, usually for examination by microscopy.

Concepts.definition: A thin slice of tissue, usually for examination by microscopy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

Concepts.definition: Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.8.15 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002731. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

Concepts.definition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

Concepts.definition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Blood that has not been separated into its various components; blood that has not been modified except for the addition of an anticoagulant.

Concepts.definition: Blood that has not been separated into its various components; blood that has not been modified except for the addition of an anticoagulant.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: DNA found in blood plasma and other bodily fluids that is not associated with cells.

Concepts.definition: DNA found in blood plasma and other bodily fluids that is not associated with cells.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A protein or RNA whose structure is represented in and determined by genomic sequences.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
